sp.l: By your favour, Sir, how have you ſped with him?
This act of yours was quite againſt my mind.
You ſee in what a poſture affairs ſtand:
And Mariana's ſoul 's e'en dead with grief;
The contract by her father newly made
At every moment makes her deſperate.
But now I have no leiſure to diſcourſe it,
Becauſe I look to meet with Tartuffe's Man;
Whoſe heart I'le ſearch: i'th' interim, if you pleaſe,
To find out Mariana and Elmira,
We will contrive ſomething that's fit to do
Or ſay to Orgon when we meet him next.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Dorina, thou haſt jumpt with my deſign;
I have prepar'd inſtructions for my Siſter.
Go, here comes Laurence—
Mind what you are about.

div.l: O Laurence! welcom; I doubt not but you have
Heard the news, and certainly in regard
Of my concerns with you it highly pleaſes me.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: What news is this?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why, that Damis is diſinherited, my young Miſtreſs
Contracted to your Maſter by her father:
And as a confirmation of that marriage,
He has enfeoffed his intended Son-in-law
In all his lands; and to make the ſame ſure
He has levied a Fine, and ſuffer'd a Recovery;
And by another Deed, upon the ſame conſideration,
Has transferr'd upon him his houſe and goods —

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: No more — then he's undone; for now let
Him be aſſur'd, if after this ought be deny'd
To his unbounded will, he'll uſe but the
Greateſt extremity towards this fond man that
Has thus fool'd himſelf, and his whole f • mily.
He no more intends to marry your Miſtreſs then
I do; he intends, if he can [and be ſure he'll
Lay hold on all opportunities] to debauch Elmira:
And if ſhe will not yield to his deſires, or make it
Known he tempted her agrn, whereby Orgon
Shou'd come to be incens'd; then nothing
Serves his turn but Utter ruine.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O Heaven defend us! now I am clearly loſt:
I know not what to do or what to adviſe,
Dear Laurence, counſell me.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Dorina, You ſee I truſt you with my ſecrets;
Be thou but true to me, and I'le direct
A way ſhall yet, I hope, produce our happineſs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What is't, dear Laurence, and I will proteſt
To give thee all in modeſty thou canſt ask,
My love, my heart, whetever I can get
I'le make thee maſter of, together with my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: You muſt procure a meeting 'twixt Elmira
And my Maſter, to which by ſome means you
Muſt make Orgon privy, that his own ears may
Witneſs to him what from the mouth of truth
He'd not believe. This muſt be done, though
For a time it breed a ſtrange confuſion, then let Cleanthes▪
Damis, and Valere inform the King and Council
Before hand of Orgons former ſervices; lay before
Them his fidelity, and pray their aid in the behalf of
Damis: for they muſt not mention any thing further;
Onely be ſure they ſtrengthen themſelves with friends,
That being prepoſſeſt may at all times be ready, as—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O my dear Laurence! if by this thy means
(As this advice is rational) we thrive,
Know thy reward ſhall ſatisfie thy merit.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Fear not: remember what I have ſaid: I doubt
I'hve ſtaid too long; I wou'd not have my Maſter
Miſs me: therefore, my dear Dorina, fare you well.
I'le ſee you ſuddenly agen. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O Heavens, what a toil is Orgon in!
This is no time for idleneſs: I'le go
And find the perſons out I long to ſpeak with:
They come.

div.head: SCEN. III.
div.l: O Madam, here's news indeed: you muſt lay your hand
To help us out of the mire. You muſt uſe
Some means to make your husband ſee this Cheat
In's colours: I'le take a care to help the reſt.
But here comes Orgon; imagine, Madam, what you had beſt
To do.
div.stage: Enter Orgon to them with a Deed, the Contract, and Tranſcript of the Fine and Recovery, and Laurence following him.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: O, I rejoyce to ſee you all together:
I've that here in my hand will make you laugh;
You know already the contents of 'em:
Laurence, ſecure theſe papers to thy Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dear Sir, in Heavens name that knows my grief, Kneels.
By every thing may move you to compaſſion,
Uſe not that pow'r you from my birth may claim,
Diſpenſe with my obedience and my vows.
Do not reduce me by this cruel act,
To wiſh to Heaven you'd never been my father.
This wretched life, alas! which you have given me,
Strive not to make it thus unfortunate.
If againſt that ſweet hope I form'd my ſelf,
You do forbid me him I've dar'd to love.
At leaſt upon my knees I do implore you,
Spare me that torment to be his I 'bhorre,
And do not make me (Sir) grow deſperate.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: This happens well to bring on the deſign. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Forbear, fond heart, and do not ſhew thy frailty. To himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I think it penetrates; alas, poor man!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your tenderneſs to him's no pain to me:
Make it more ſignal; let him have your wealth:
If that ſuffice not, adde what e'r is mine;
For ever I conſent, and will forſake it:
But do not give ſo far, Sir, as my perſon.
Suffer th' auſterities of a Nunnery,
To paſs away thoſe hours which Heaven has lent me.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Yes, you are very fit to be religious,
Now when you feel your amorous flames depreſs'd.
Stand up; the more your heart denies to have him,
'Twill offer you th'occaſion of more merit.
Come, mortifie your ſenſes by thi • marriage,
And do not vex me any more about it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What, Sir—

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Be ſilent, Huſſie; ſpeak when you are ſp • ak to.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: If by advice you'll ſuffer me to anſwer—.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Brother, your Councels are the beſt i'th' world,
They're full of reaſon, and I prize them much.
But you muſt pardon me, if I refuſe 'em.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: Seeing what I have ſeen, I can ſay nothing,
But ſilent ſtand in admiration at you.
Your love has blinded you to that degree,
T'affirm us liars in what you'll find too true.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Your ſervant, Madam, I perceive your drift,
And know your correſpondence with my ſon;
You are afraid he ſhould diſown that plot,
Which you deſign'd againſt that vertuous man.
You were too patient to perſwade belief;
Had it been true, you wou'd have chang'd your humour,
And ſhew'd your ſelf mov'd in another manner.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O rare! he brings it on himſelf! aſide.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: Againſt the Proſpect of an amorous Motion,
Muſt we draw all the force our Honours have?
May we not anſwer thoſe who do attempt us,
But with injurious mouths, eyes full of fire?
For my part I but laugh at ſuch Propoſals,
And do not care to make a noiſe about 'em.
I love in mildneſs we ſhould ſhew our wiſdom;
Nor did I e're eſteem a ſavage prudence
In them whoſe Honours, arm'd with teeth and nails,
For every little word ſcratch people's Faces.
From all ſuch rudeneſs Heav'n preſerve me,
I do not love ſuch divel-natur'd vertue.
The diſcreet coolneſs of a chaſte denial,
Is far more pow'rful to rebuke a Villain.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: In ſhort, I'm ſatisfi'd; I know the truth.

sp.speaker: Elm
sp.l: Agen, I'm aſtoniſht at your weakneſs.
What will your incredulity anſwer me,
If you ſhould ſee what we have ſaid is true.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O incomparably done! aſide.

sp.speaker: O g.
sp.p: See? what I wonder? ſee?

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: Yes, ſo I ſay, ſee:

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: You're very pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: How if I finde a way
To make you ſee all this i'th open light?

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Caſtles in th' Air!

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: Strange man! give me your anſwer;
I don't perſwade you to believe it neither;
But ſuppoſe now I ſhould finde out a place
To let you clearly ſee, and hear each paſſage,
What wou'd you ſay then to your vertuous man;

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: I'de ſay in ſuch a caſe — I wou'd ſay nothing.
For it can't be.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: The errour holds too long;
It does condemn my tongue too of impoſture.
Let me for paſtime without ſtirring further
To all that I have told you make you witneſs.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Be't ſo; I'le take your word, and ſee your cunnin •
Which way you're able to fulfill your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: Go, fetch him hither.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Madam, he's very ſubtil,
And I believe it difficult to ſurpriſe him.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: No, no, we're eaſily caught by what we love.
Bid him come down, and (pray) do you retire.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: Draw near the Table, and creep you under it,

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: Be ſure you be not ſeen.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Why under the Table?

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: Nay, nay, ask no queſtions.
My deſign's here, and you ſhall judge on't preſently.
Go, get you under't▪ and when you're there
Take heed that you be neither heard nor ſeen.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: My condeſcenſion muſt be great in this:
I long to ſee the project at an end.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: You will be puzzled ſtrait to play your part;
I • m going now about a tickliſh buſineſs,
At which you may be ſcandaliz'd, but I
Will give no cauſe, although I take the freedom,
By your permiſſion, to ſay all I'm able,
That ſo I may convince you, as I've promis'd.
I am conſtrain'd againſt the rules of honour,
To wear a mask to catch the hypocrite:
And if I ſeem to flatter his deſires,
Or yield a freedom to his raſh attempts,
'Tis for your ſake, the better to confound him.
My ſoul deſigns all this—
I ſhall retire as ſoon as you appear,
And things ſhall go no further then you'd have 'em▪
'Tis you muſt ſtop his courſe, and cool the heat
Of his inflamed Zele, when you perceive
Your Honour is concern'd; and then, I hope,
Your eyes will diſabuſe that credulous humour,
That made you ſlight both intereſt and friends.
You ſhall be Maſter here— No more, he comes;
Take heed he don't diſcover you.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: They told me, Madam, you would ſpeak with me.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: Yes, I have a ſecret to reveal to you;
But ſhut the door, and ſearch about the chamber;
I am unwilling we ſhould be ſurpriz'd.
sp.stage: He goes back and bolts the door.
sp.l: An accident like that laſt happen'd to us,
Wou'd now be more unwelcome then before.
Damis did fright me ſtrangely for your ſake;
But you perceiv'd, I hope, there was no want
Of will in me to change the Scene, and turn
His rage 'gainſt you into a quiet calm.
I muſt confeſs, I was ſo much amazed,
That I had no invention to diſguiſe it.
But, Heaven be praiſed! it prov'd all for the beſt,
And things are now in more ſecurity:
Your eſtimation has allay'd the ſtorm,
And Orgon (to out-brave the peoples vogue)
Allows us freer converſe at all times.
Hence it proceeds, that without fear of blame
I ſee my ſelf lock'd up with you alone.
This has emboldened me to open an heart
Unable longer to reſiſt your love.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: 'Tis difficult to comprehend this language;
You lately, Madam, talk'd another ſtyle.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: If that denial, Sir, did anger you,
You have ſmall knowledge of a womans heart.
Our Modeſties pretend to give you battel:
Even in that inſtant we intend ſurrender,
With the ſame reaſons we diſown our loves.
We do proclaim 'em, and that very moment
Our tongues in honour do oppoſe our wiſhes:
The weakneſs of refuſal is a promiſe.
In thee my freedom without doubt I've made,
But very little uſe of modeſty—
And ſince the word is out e'ne let it go.
D'ye think I wou'd have ſtay'd with ſo muce mildneſs,
To liſten to the proffer of your love,
Or wou'd have taken things with ſuch a calm,
If th' offer of your heart had not been pleaſing?

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: 'Tis Madam, without doubt▪ a mighty happineſs
To hear ſuch language from a Mouth of love;
The honey of your words drop on my ſenſes,
Such a ſuavity was never taſted.
My chiefeſt ſtudy ſtill has been to pleaſe you;
But yet my heart demands the liberty,
To doubt a little its beatitude
If I may liberally expound my ſelf;
Such ſoft Propoſals I can ſcarce miſtruſt:
Might I but taſte thoſe favou • s that I ſigh for
It wou'd aſſure me much of all you ſay;
And in my boſom plant a conſtant faith,
Of all thoſe charming bounties you have for me.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: What in ſuch haſte; Nay Mr Tartuffe, Fye;
sp.stage: She coughs to advertiſe her husband.
sp.l: Theſe greateſt favours are not gain'd at once:
I almoſt dy'd t' unfold my thoughts to you,
And yet you ſeem not to be ſatisfi'd:
You have not ſhew'd ſuch courage as wou'd merit
Thoſe higheſt favours to be granted by us.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: The leſs I merit, the leſs I dare to hope for;
And this diſcourſe does not confirm my wiſh:
We are ſuſpicious of a haſty fortune:
Yet wou'd enjoy before we can believe it.
I have ſo little merited this bounty,
That I ſuſpect the happy conſequence;
Th • s Madam makes me ſlow in my belief,
Ti • l you convince me by reality.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: Your love does act like a fierce Tyrant, Sir;
Taking a furious ſoveraignty o're hearts,
And preſſes to its end with too much violence.
What will you not allow me time to breathe?
D'ye think this rigour does become you, Sir?
To preſs ſo hard upon my feeble weakneſs?

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: But ſince you have reſpect for my addreſſes,
Why d'ye refuſe to give me pledges of it?

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: Pray how can I conſent to what you'd have,
Without offending Heaven?

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: If that be all
A little thing removes that obſt • cle.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: But I do dread what is by Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: Such fe • rs are vain, I can remove theſe ſcruples.
'Tis true, Heaven does forbid us cert • in pleaſures,
But there remains a means for compoſition:
We may abate the evil of our actions,
By the ſincerity of our intentio • s,
Diſpoſe your ſelf to me for your ſafe conduct:
Content but my deſire, and fear nothing;
I'le anſwer all, and take the ſin on me.
You cough extremely, Madam.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: Yes, I have caught cold.
sp.stage: Aſide; Tranſcendent Villain! this language proves thee ſo▪

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: Pleaſe you to take ſome juice of Liquoriſh.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: This rheum is obſtinate without, I ſee;
That all the juice i'th' world will do no good!

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: 'Tis very troub • eſom.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: Ye, beyond expreſſion.

sp.speaker: Tart
sp.l: In ſhort, your ſcruple's eaſily deſtroyed;
I will aſſure y • u this great ſecret,
The ſin is when we make it publick, Madam;
Th'offence is i • lodg'd i'th' ſc •• dal of the world:
We do not ſin when we do act in ſecret.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: Well, Sir; I ſee, I muſt reſolve to yield,
And find my ſelf conſenting to your will.
sp.stage: Speaks ſubtilly, addreſſing her ſelf to both.
sp.l: I ought not to pretend to leſs then this,
That I'm content, and willing now to render;
But yet it grieves me too to come thus far;
And 'tis againſt my will I am thus free:
Yet ſince the obſtinate wo'nt now deliver me,
And wo'not yet believe what I have ſaid,
But does deſire more pregnant teſtimonies,
I muſt reſolve immediate ſatisfaction.
If this conſent of mine be an offence,
The worſt is theirs who force this violence.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I'le diſcharge your care in this—

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: See if my husband be'nt i'th' Gallery.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: What need you, Madam, take ſuch care of him?
He is a man that we can • ead by th' noſe.
He glories, Madam, in our entertainments,
And wo'nt believe it though he ſee it done.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: I wo'not truſt to that, go out, I pray,
sp.stage: Tartuffe goes out awhile, and comes in agen.
sp.l: And look about exactly every where.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: What an abominable Villain's this!
I'm almoſt ready to ſink down to hear it▪

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: What do you mock me, you come out ſo quickly?
Go under agen, it is not yet full time;
Stay to the end th • t you ſee all things ſure,
And do not truſt to ſimple poor conjectures.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Nothing ſo wicked ever ſprung from Hell.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: You ſhou'd not be ſo light in your belief;
Be ſure you are convinc'd before you appear:
Don't haſte too much leſt you miſtake your ſelf.
sp.stage: Tartuffe comes in, and ſhe puts her husband behind her.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: All things conſpire to make our pleaſures full:
I have • ook'd every where in your Appartment,
And find no perſon; Oh! my ſoul is raviſh'd—

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Hold; Sir;
You proſecute your love too faſt.
Your amorous paſſion is too violent.
Ah, honeſt man! have you not prov'd it now?
How does your ſoul reſiſt all foul temptations?
Marry my daughter, and debauch my wife?
I doubted a long time this was not ſo;
And did believe that they were baſe aſperſions:
But now theſe teſtimonies are ſo paipable.
That I have done, and will deſire no more.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: Againſt my humour I have done all this;
But I was forced to't to retrive my honour.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: What do you think—

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Be gone, no noiſe, I pray—
No ceremony, but avoid your neſt.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: My deſign —

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis no time to talk:
You muſt march off, quickly depart my houſe.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: Nay then farewell diſſembling; I'le not ſtir.
Tis you muſt march you Sir, you that Lord it ſo:
I'le make you know the houſe belongs to me;
And quickly ſhew you 'tis a vain attempt
By ſuch weak ſtratagems to evade my right:
You are not where you think by this baſe injury;
I will confound and puniſh your impoſture,
Revenge the Heavens you've wronged, and make you all
Repent the motion of my going hence.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: What means this language? what is'c he would ſay?

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: I am confus'd, this is no time for raillery.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: I ſee my fault by what he now has uttered.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: Laurence, look you to the chamber, and be ſure
You're careful of the cabinet ſtands there.
Orgon himſelf delivered it to me,
And I will give't the King to ruine him.
If any offer to intrude, be quick,
And pocket up the writings with the ſeals;
While I immediately find out the Sheriff.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Yes, I'le look to them ſure, and keep them ſafe
From you for ever, Sir. O horrid traitor!
Admitted into Orgons houſe on courteſie,
And now would rudely turn him out of doors▪

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O Laurence, Laurence, we're all undone!
Orgon, I think, 's diſtracted: I believe
You can unfold the riddle: you promiſed me—

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: No more then; I'le perform, ſtay but here,
I'le return preſently.
sp.stage: Laurence goes out, and ſhortly returns with cabinet and writing in his hand.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This man, I ſee, will merit my eſteem.
He told me the experiment that muſt f
But he would find a means to ſettle all.
And here he comes already i'th' name of goodneſs:
What has he there? what loaded, Laurence?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: You ſee what love will do, Dorinna; this
And this I here deliver to your hands.
It is of value, I aſſure you Girle.
Keep theſe till I give further notice to you
Of what is to be done: theſe will do more
Then what I promiſed.
And if you weet with gratitude, then ſay,
Laurence has clearly won me by fair play.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: VVEll met, Cleanthes; what have you done at Court?
The ſtorm is rais'd; have you done
What I advis'd you? whe • e's Damis and Valere?
I'de have you bring home Damis inſtantly;
His preſence now will be convenient.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Why, faith Dorina, I perceived 'twas time;
There's need enough of all the help of friends:
And ſure, I think, we have don't. We have obtained
A Warrant Dormant to bring Tartuffe in,
To ſhew the Council cauſe why he pretends
T'intrude on Damis heritage: and more,
The King and Council will by Order have
The father reconciled to his ſon;
But this is all ſo private, no one knows
Ought of it, onely thoſe peculiar Lords
That did engage, and opened Orgons merit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Well then, Cleanthes, we ſhall ſee ſome ſport;
And when it comes to th'iſſue 'twill appear,
I have been active in another ſphere.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Whither d'ye run?

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Alas I know not, Brother.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Methinks we rather ſhould conſult together,
What we had beſt to do in this ext e •• ity.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Oh! had I but the Cabinet out of's hands,
I wou'd not fear his malice: but alas!
I drives me almoſt to deſpair the thought of't.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Pray what important myſtery was in it?

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: I was a pawn my dear friend Argas left me
Of his great love: no witneſs being by;
And at his flight 'mongſt all his friends choſe me
To be the faithful Guardian of his fortune;
But now he has juſt reaſon to upbraid me:
They're papers that contain his life and treaſure.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Why did you truſt them then in other hands?

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: 'Twas by a motive from a Caſe of Conſcience.
I in this Traitor put my confidence,
Whoſe Arguments did ſoon prevail upon me,
To give the Cabinet into his Cuſtody.
That if a ſtrict Enquiry ſhould be made
After the fugitive I might be ready,
Without the prejudicing of my ſoul,
To take my Oath againſt a real truth.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: In all appearance you're in a bad condition,
What with your feoffment, fine, and other deed.
If I may freely give my judgment of it,
You've taken a certain way to finde out Ruine.
Oh Sir! this man has ſtrange advantages,
Being poſſeſt of ſuch ſtrong pledges from you,
It were imprudence to provoke him, Sir;
You ought to ſearch out now ſome milder way.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: What! under the ſhadow of a fervent zeal,
Shrowd ſuch a double heart and haughty mind!
I took him up a beggar, having nothing —
'Tis done; now I renounce all honeſt men;
Henceforward I ſhall hate the ſight of them,
And be more envious to them then the devil.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Fie brother! this is juſt your cholerick humour;
Do not forſake the pleaſant rode of temperance,
But let fair moderation be your conduct:
From one exceſs you'll fall into another;
You ſee your errour, and you have acknowledg'd it,
How through a feign'd pure zeal you have been cheated,
What reaſon is there to correct this fault.
That you ſhou'd run into a greater Treſpaſs:
What cauſe this Raſcal's confidence has trapan'd you,
With an auſtere pretence of pure devotion;
Do you believe that every one's like him,
And that one true religious can't be found?
Leave this bad conſequence to Libertines,
But do not hazard your eſteem too much,
But ſtill preſerve it in the golden mean.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: I am raging mad to finde my ſelf thus cheated.

div.head: SCEN. III.
div.stage: Enter Pernelle, Mariana, Elmira, Dorina, to them.

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.p: What's here to do, I'm told moſt terrible myſteries.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: They'r Novelties, mine eyes have witneſs't Mother.
You ſee how all my love is recompenc'd.
With zeal I pluck'd this man from miſery,
Lodg'd him and entertain'd him like a brother,
I heap'd my favours on him every day,
Setled my Lands upon him with intent
To marry him to my Daughter; aſſign'd to him
My houſe, my goods, my Jewels with all in't;
Yet the ſame time this baſe perfidious ſlave
Made it his buſineſs to debauch my wife;
And not contented with this horrid act,
Dares now to menace me with my own benefits.
And take advantage by 'em to my ruine.
Arm'd with my fooliſh bounty comes againſt me,
To drive me from my eſtate transfer'd to him,
And ſo reduce me to his native beggery.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas poor man!

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.l: I can't believe this ſon,
That he wou'd e re conceive ſo black an action.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: How? not believ't?

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.p: Honeſt people ſtill are envi'd ſon.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: What wou'd you ſay if you cou'd ſpeak good Mother?

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.l: I ſay your family is ſtrangely govern'd;
And 'tis well known the malice they all bear him.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: What ſignifies all this to that I've told you?

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.l: I've told you a hundred times when you were little,
That vertue always ſuffers perſecution;
The envious muſt die, but envy never.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: What's this diſcourſe to that is done to day?

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.p: They've forg'd a hundred fooliſh tales againſt him.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: I told you I had ſeen all this my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.p: The malice is extreme of lying people.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: O! you confound me! I tell you once age •
My eyes have ſeen this impudent bold crime.

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.l: Their tongues are always full of horrid venom,
Theres no defence againſt it here on earth.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: You talk as if you were bereft of ſenſe,
I have ſeen't I tell you, ſeen't; my own eyes ſee it.
Whate they call ſeeing: I'le not bate you an ace,
I'le bawle't a hundred times into your ears.

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.l: O Heav'n! how often is the ſight deceiv'd!
You ſhou'd not always judge of what you ſee.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: You make me mad, ſtark mad! O curſed folly!

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.l: Nature is much inclin'd to falſe ſuſpicions,
And often does interpret good for evil.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: I ought to think it charitable care
For him to kiſs my wife!

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.l: 'Tis neceſſary,
That you take heed how you accuſe good people:
You ſhou'd have ſtay • d till you had ſeen things ſure.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Ah Curſe! the means how to be more aſſur'd?
Wou'd you have had me ſtay'd t' have ſeen my wife.—
— You'll force me to extravigant diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.l: In fine, too pure a zeal had chaam'd his ſoul:
I cannot make it enter my belief,
☞ He ſhou'd attempt to do theſe things you talk of.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: Alas! poor man!

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Go; were you not my Mother, I can't tell
What I ſhould ſay t'ye. I'm ſo much confus'd.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis a juſt vengeance, for you heretofore
Had no belief; and now none believe you.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: We trifle out that time in vain diſcourſe,
Shou'd be employ'd for to prevent this cheat.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: I cannot apprehend he dares attempt it;
His baſe ingratitude is too manifeſt.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yes truſt him ſtill; think you he han't confederates,
That will adde all their cunning to his force;
And more then that the weight of a Cabal
Will bring us into ſome confuſed Labyrinth..

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: 'Tis true, what's my beſt courſe? this Villain's pride
Makes me I cannot maſter my reſentments.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Come, chear up, brother; my ſelf, your ſon Valere,
With all our friends will meet this monſtrous Villain,
And ſee what we can do t'avoid this Precipice.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: If I had known he had bin ſo ſtrongly arm'd,
I never wou'd have caus'd half theſe alarmes.
And for — Loyal peeps in.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: VVhat wou'd that man? quickly go know his buſineſs;
I'm very ill diſpos'd for converſation.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.l: Pray will you inform the Gentleman of the houſe.
I have ſome buſineſs with him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He is with Company.
And for the preſent Sir, will ſpeak with no body.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.l: I will not be importunote at this time,
Though ſure my coming, as I think, will pleaſe him.
And 'tis about a buſineſs he'll be glad of.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your Name?

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.l: Pray tell him only that I come
From Mr. Tartuffe, and deſire a word with him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir, here's a modeſt Gentleman that comes
In the behalf of Mr. Tartuffe to you.
He ſays about a buſineſs you'll be glad of.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You had beſt diſcourſe with him, and know his buſineſs.
Perhaps he comes to make a Compoſition.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: With what reſentments ſhall I entertain him?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: I wou'd not have you, Sir, be paſſionate.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.l: Save you Sir, may Heav'n proſper you,
And ſcatter all thoſe enemies wou'd hurt you.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Methinks this Complement does ſeem to tell me,
His buſineſs is for an accommodation.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.l: Your family was always dear to me;
I had the honour, Sir, to ſerve your father.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Sir, I am aſham'd, I humbly beg your pardon;
I have forgot you, let me crave your Name.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.l: My name is Loyal, a North-Countrey man;
And now, Sir, with your leave, know I am come
To give you this declaration, 'tis in an Action
Of ejectment, Sir, at Mr. Tartuffe's ſuit.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: At Tartuffe's ſuit; oh Villain!

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.l: Sir, be not raſh;
Although it be to turn out you and yours;
It is not preſently; if you have ought to plead
Againſt a Deed made on good Conſideration,
You may, elſe muſt turn out.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Muſt I turn out?

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.l: Yes Sir;
Unleſs you can prevent it, as I told you.
But much I'm afraid you're in the Mire.
The forme is good, it cannot be deni'd.
But I'le for bear you till tomorrow Morning.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: I ſtand amaz'd at this ſtrange impudence. Cleanthes gives Loyal money.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Sir, I have done my errand, arm your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Arm my ſelf? what, without weapons?

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.l: Sir, I can ſay no more, you muſt be quick
And circumſpect in your defence; farewell.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Loyal d'ye call him? he has a Traitors face.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Well, now he's gone, what courſe is to be taken?
Our time is ſhort, but till tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Be patient, Brother, my phanſie bodes you good.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Now look you, Mother, ſee if I have not reaſon;
And you may judge the reſt by this exploit.
What, are his Villanies manifeſt to you now?

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.p: I'm almoſt dead with my aſtoniſhment.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You falſly grieve, and blame him wrongfully:
This but confirms his ſpiritual deſign.
His love to's neighbour does compleat his virtue; In raillery to Orgon.
He knows that riches do corrupt the ſoul;
And in pure charity has taken from you
The chiefeſt hindrance of your felicity. Dorina pulls Cleanthes and goes off.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: What muſt I always bid you hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Come, let us ſee what we had beſt to do.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: Go and declare his baſe ungrateful ſoul;
It may enervate this your Deed of Gift,
When his diſloyalty ſhall appear ſo black,
And hinder that ſucceſs he hopes t'obtain.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: The matter's ripe, it muſt no further run;
I'le go and find out Damis and Valere,
And give an Information 'gainſt this Villain,
That he may be ſecur'd; in th'interim you
Go find out Laurence, that his zele to us
At th'upſhot may receive a due reward.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What would this man have done?
Ruin'd the hopes and glory of his family.
Laurence, thou haſt deſerv'd well at his hands:
Thy faith to me has ſav'd his whole eſtate.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Dorina, how go ſquares? I hear ſtrange news,
But 'tis ſo much at random, I can make
Nor head nor tail on't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Stay but awhile, and you ſhall ſee th' event.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: No; we'll go walk awhile abroad, and then
In half an hour return to know th'effect.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The work is done, the Villain is ſecur'd,
And does not know it yet, but thinks he's Victor.
We have the Deed and Cabinet; by theſe means
The Traitors malice ceaſes, and all's ſafe—
But we muſt fright Orgon. You ſhall, Cleanthes,
Go to the Meſſenger, in whoſe cuſtody
Tartuffe remains at preſent, and bring with him
His priſoner, as if he came to put
Him in poſſeſſion. I will go before,
Feigning to tell the news, and make him fly;
Then Damis ſhall appe • r, whom I'le preſent
As ruin'd by his folly; and after that
Laurence ſhall bring Dorina t'act her part.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How ſhall we make the Meſſenger to ſerve us,
And act his part?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Let that alone to me;
I with a little money
Will buy him over to do what I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come let's away, and put't in agitation.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: I wonder that my brother comes not at me.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: He's like the world flies from a falling houſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I think not ſo, I rather muſt believe,
He's acting for your Intereſt what he can.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: With a regret I come t'afflict you, Sir:
But I'm conſtrain'd to't by a preſſing danger.
A friend of mine, whoſe amity is ſtrong,
And knew the Intereſt I ought to have in you,
Has violated out of curioſity
The ſecreſie due to th'affairs of State.
And even now he ſent me this advice,
Which muſt reduce you to a ſudden flight:
That Slave to whom you did commit your truſt,
Within this hou • accus'd you to the King,
And has deliver'd Cabinet of importance,
Which makes your friend and you both Malefactors;
And by miſpriſion of a Subjects duty,
Y'have private kept the ſecrets of a Traitor.
I'm ignorant of the title of your crime:
But Order's given, Sir, to arreſt your perſon;
And for the better execution on't,
Tartuffe is ſent with thoſe that are to take you.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: He has prov'd himſelf a monſtrous wicked Rogue.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: the leaſt delay may prove, Sir, fatal to you.
My Coach does now attend you at your Gate;
Let's loſe no time to avoid this thunder clap,
For theſe are blows onely put by, by flight.
To a ſure place I proffer you my conduct,
And will accompany you to your journeys end.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: What don't I owe for theſe obliging cares?
And now, Sir, I want time to give you thanks:
But I beg Heaven to be propitious to me,
That I may live to pay your generous ſervice.
Farewell— pray take a care.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Make haſte.

div.head: SCEN. ULT.
div.stage: Enter Cleanthes running, and followed by the Meſſenger. Orgon runs, and the Meſſenger ſtays him.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Softly, Sir, ſoftly; do not run ſo faſt;
You have not far to go to find your lodging:
Know, Sir, that you are priſoner to the King.

div.stage: Enter Tartuffe with two or three Officers. Orgon ſpies him.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Judas, Thou haſt kept this treachery till the laſt.
Monſter! by this vile blow thou haſt undone me;
And by it thou haſt crown'd thy Villany.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: You muſt not give ſuch terms they'l not avail you.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: I can diſpenſe with theſe injurious words.
For I am taught by Heaven to ſuffer all.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I do aver thy moderation great,
Impudent Rogue! that thus dares play with Heaven.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: O Brother, where's my ſon?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: How can you ask for him you have undone?

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, hold off your hand, I will not ſtir.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: Do but reflect how good he was to you.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: All you can ſay ſhall have no power to move me;
I dream of nothing but to do my duty.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You pretend much glory from this action.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: And this employment too becomes you well.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: The employment cannot but be honourable,
Deriv'd from that high power which ſent me hither.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Haſt thou forgot that charitable hand,
Ingrateful man, that pluck'd thee out of miſery?

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: Sir, I am ſenſible of all your favours;
But my Kings ſervice is my higheſt duty;
And the remembrance of that ſacred tie
Stifles the thought of any reſtitution.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Good Mr. Tartuffe, if you pleaſe, withdraw;
You know your buſineſs, Sir, is ſure enough.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: I will retire to avoid contention, Sir;
But pray diſpatch and rid my houſe of 'em.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: O impudence unmatchable! thy houſe?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Come, what a noiſe is here? I'le ſtay no longer.
I charge you come with me immedi • tely
Into the priſon, where you muſt remain.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Have patience, Sir, a little; I'le engage for him.
Upon your word I'le ſtay a little longer.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Orgon, what do you mean? I am afraid
You are to ſeek: but, pray, reſolve me, this;
Suppoſe your friends ſhould move the King and Council
In your behalf, wou'd you not run anew
Into freſh errours?

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: No, Cleanthes, never.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: We'll try what can be done, pray ſtay a while.

sp.speaker: Meſs.
sp.l: I wiſh they may prevail, but I much doubt it
Unleſs they work it ſtrongly.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: I know not what to ſay, Heav'n ſpeed 'em well,
But ſee deſpair hath ſtopt his journey. Brother, what ails thee?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I met Dorina at the door, who ſtopt me,
And ſaid ſhe had ſome welcom news to tell you.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Where is ſhe:

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: I left her talking to a friend, ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir, I am ſorry to ſee you
In ſuch affliction as you are, but patience.

div.stage: Enter a Servant, and Whiſpers Clean.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Damis is without, and deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Bid him come in.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Alas! dear Sir. What's the matter here?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your father here is ſeiz'd, I cannot ſay
His cr me, but think the puniſhment is juſt
For his abuſing you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: I've no reſentment of that hard uſage, Sir,
But wiſh in this affair my power could
Support my will.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Oh ſon! this pious duty in you makes me ſeem
Odious unto my ſelf, and therefore friend
Carry me where you will.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: See brother, here's Dorina, who has oft
Told you to what your follies would reduce you:
But as I ſaid, ſhe now has other news.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: I have enough, lay no more weights of grief
Upon my heart: Heav'n ſend it may be good.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir, hearing of the troubles which were fallen
Upon you, thorow your own indiſcretion;
And knowing, in adverſity a friend
Is worth acceptance; I have brought one hither.
That with that Gentleman's leave; will dare to bail you,
He has from me receiv'd an information,
Your crime is neither Felony nor Treaſon:
And the worſt priſon you deſerve for this
Is Bedlam: if you will accept the offer,
And theſe Gentlemen be pleaſed with't,
I'le call him in.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Do ſo, with all our hearts, I ſpeak for all.

div.stage: Enter Laurence with a Cabinet and Writings. Dorina with the Aſſignment.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir, here's the man!

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: What Laurence! Tartuffe's man!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Prithee let's ſee it done.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Sir, how far my quondam Maſter has trangerſt
I don't examine, for I hear already
He's call'd to account; I at D • r • na's inſtance, come
To tender the beſt ſervices I can;
And though my fortune place me in the croud,
But few degrees from beggery, yet I have
A heart as generous as the nobleſt of you.
See Gentlemen, I freely this beſtow.
On Orgon as a Preſent of my Love;
And my Dorina is the ſole reward.
I ask for all.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir if the love and care of this man here
Had not been great to me, I had not had
This opportunity to do you ſervice;
But by his means, Sir, I am able now
To quiet your poſſeſſion in this houſe.
Here Sir—

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: O Heav'n what do I ſee, Cleanthes, this
Is that ſame very deed I made to Tartuffe.
See, there's your Guardian Angel; O Dorina
Thou ſhalt no more be ſervile, we will all
Submit to our Protectreſs, our Defender.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dorina, my Dorina, thou haſt maſter'd me.
If I ſhou'd ſtudy all my life to ſerve thee,
I cou'd not make a ſuitable return.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.l: Deareſt Dorina, thou haſt once more made,
Me Myſtriſs of this place; my ſelf and Orgon
Are bound to bleſs that moment brought thee hither.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My Siſter is tranſported with her joy.
Intruth Dorina thou haſt ſurpriz'd us all,
What Damis, Valere, and my ſelf could not
Imagine how to compaſs, thou didſt do.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: We will not ask the means, but render thanks
To bleſsed Heav'n for this delivery: I am convinc'd and hate the Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: There ſtands the means—
Thank him: neither my policy or ſtrength
Cou'd e're have reach'd it, it was his deſign.
He brought the things to me; not ſought or courted,
But truly of himſelf, and when he ſaw
All things were even beyond remedy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Laurence, I here perceive we are all bound
To your fidelity, for which in the behalf
Of all I promiſe a reward —
And now, Cleanthes, let us clear the miſt.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: What is the reaſon of this long demurre?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Sir, you have done your duty, and wi hou • fear,
May let your priſ'ner [Orgon I mean] go free.

sp.speaker: Meſs.
sp.l: Sir, you're as free as Ayre; my task is here.
This is indeed my priſ'ner.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: How I your pris'ner!

sp.speaker: Meſs.
sp.p: Yes Sir! behold my warrant.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: How various are the bleſſings of this life!

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Where am I? in a dream; are my eyes open?
Is this my houſe, and theſe in truth my friends?
This is a change ſo unexpected that
It was beyond my hopes.—

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Sir, here's your ſon. and ſon-in-law; to both
You're equally oblig'd, though both caſt off
Yet left not ſtill to intercede at Court,
And ſo at laſt prevail'd [upon the hearing
The former ſervice you had done repeated]
That both the King and Council did declare
The acts you did invalid;
And pardon'd your connivance with that Traitor,
But how to unravel this was all the work—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let me tell that, Cleanthes, 'twas your Genius
• rought it to thi • perfection. He, Sir, perceiving▪
How ſtrongly you had noos'd your ſelf by Law,
Accuſes Tartuffe of prodigious crimes:
Crimes that entrencht on Royal Majeſty,
Which he confirm'd by noble Witneſſes;
Then did he get a Grant of all th' eſtate
Tartuffe had got from you: by which ſecur'd
The Villain cou'd not harm you; we deſign'd
To try your patience; as you ſee w'have done.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Sir, if any former faults I did commit;
I humbly here implore your pardon for 'em.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Talk not of faults, this is a time of joy,
Let us return our duty in our thanks
To his Moſt Gracious Majeſty, that did
So nobly lend his Princely ear to you.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: But let not Laurence be forgotten here;
And let Dorina's merits be rewarded.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: What they deſire I'll give.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: With your favour, my reward ſhall be,
Dorina, if your Daughter will conſent.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: With all my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.p: Are you agreed Dorina.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Elſe had your Deed and Cabinet be gone.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Laurence, how deep m'engagements to you are,
Though yet I know not fully to let you ſee
Before my friends here preſent, that I mean

To gratifie your honeſty; here take Dorina.
Gives Dorina to him.
And with her a hundred pounds a year in portion
During your lives, and the Survivor of you.

sp.speaker: Laur
sp.p: We both will pray for your eternal happineſs.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: And for you, Valere, whoſe true affection
Unto the Daughter, made you the Father's Advocate,
Take this as Pledge. Takes Mariana by the hand, and gives her to Valere.
Valere, be happy in her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh Laurence! I am raviſh'd with my joy.

sp.speaker: Pern.
sp.p: Truly, la! I am conforted agen.

sp.speaker: Elm.
sp.p: O moſt propitious ſtars! moſt bleſt ſucceſs!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Who cou'd have dar'd t'have hop't this happineſs?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Siſter, you have a Jewel, prize him high.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thank you brother; and to crown our joys
I promiſe here to give my Siſter to you,
So ſoon as I can ſend for her to Town.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: I'm bleſt in ſuch a Brother, and a friend.
How happy is that Kingdom, where the Prince
Himſelf does ſteer the Royal Helm of State;
That rul'd by reaſon, gives to honeſt men
The praiſe they merit, and decrees for ſuch
As are fair vertues enemies, a pain
Or puniſhment proportion'd to their crime.

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: What, Brother, in a rapture? Let us go
And ſhew our grateful duty in our deeds.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: As for this Tartuffe, miſerable wretch,
Leave him to's fate, and let his ſins o'rewhelm him.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.l: Ah Laurence, Laurence, thou art a wicked fellow;
But Heaven, I truſt, will vindicate my cauſe.

div.stage: Excunt Meſſenger and Tartuffe; the Officers hale him off the Stage.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Forbear your canting, Sir, I know your inſide.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, Gentlemen, we muſt not part thus dully:
'Tis fit our hearts expreſs our happineſs;
And joyning in a dance begin thoſe ſports,
Which after marriage ſhall be more enlarg'd.

div.stage: [The Dance ended, Orgon riſes and ſpeaks▪ ]

sp.speaker: Org.
sp.l: Let's now with joy unto His Majeſty,
And at his Royal Feet proſtrate our ſelves,
Acknowledging his generous favours to us▪
Then in purſuance of our great devoir,
Let us compleat this happy Lovers bliſs.
Proceeding for their Nuptials, as we are tied
In gratitude to Laurence and Dorina,
Whoſe ſervices deſerve a large requital:
And by ſweet Hymen's help crown in Valere
A Lovers flame both generous and ſincere.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: MAny have been the vain Attempts of Wit,
Againſt the ſtill-prevailing Hypocrite.
Once (and but once) a Poet got the day,
And vanquiſh't Buſy in a Puppet-Play.
But Buſy rallying, Arm'd with Zeal and Rage,
Poſſeſt the Pulpit and pull'd down the Stage.
To laugh at Engliſh Knaves is dangerous then,
Whilſt Engliſh Fools will think 'em honeſt Men.
But ſure no zealous Rabby will deny us
Free leave to act our Monſieur Ananias.
A man may ſay (without being thought an Atheiſt)
There are damn'd Regues amongſt the French and Papiſt,
That fix Salvation to ſhort Bands and Hair,
That belch and ſnuffle to prolong a Prayer.
That uſe (enjoy the Creature) to expreſs
Plain Whoring, Gluttony, and Drunkenneſs;
And in a decent way Perform 'em too,
As well, nay better far alas then you:
Whoſe fleſhly failings are but Fornication,
We Godly phraſe it, Goſpel Propagation;
Juſt as Rebellion was call'd Reformation.
Though Zeal ſtand, Centry at the Gate of Sin,
Yet all that have the Word paſs freely in;
Silent and in the dark for fear of Spies
We march, and take damnation by ſurpriſe:
There's not a Roaring Blade about the Town
Can go ſo far towards Hell for half a Crown,
As I for ſ • x pence; 'cauſe I know the way:
For want of Guides men are too apt to ſtray.
Therefore Give car to what I ſhall Adviſe,
Let every married man that's Rich and Wiſe;
Take a Tartuffe of known Ability,
To Teach, and to Increaſe his Family,
Who may to ſettle laſting R • formation,
Firſt Get his Son, then Give him Education,
